content:
Speculation about those responsible for bombing churches and hotels focuses on jihadist groups

IT HAS BEEN nearly ten years since the guns fell silent in Sri Lanka’s civil war. But bloodshed returned with a vengeance on Easter Sunday when a succession of explosions ripped through three churches packed with worshippers, and three five-star hotels. At least 207 people were killed and hundreds more were injured.

The coincidence of the attacks with the upcoming anniversary of the Sri Lankan army’s defeat of the Tamil Tiger rebels on May 19th—ending a war that pitted the ethnic Tamil and a largely Hindu minority, against the Sinhalese Buddhist majority—may be just that. The authorities are being cautious about apportioning blame, particularly because of the recent history of communal violence on the island, both during and after the war.

A senior police official said there were signs the six blasts were all suicide bombings. This was a favourite tactic of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, but no fingers are being pointed at any Tamil groups. And suicide tactics, especially aimed at religious targets and foreign tourists, are also a hallmark of international jihadist groups. Yet the country has little history of jihadist activity.

The explosions were the deadliest attacks in the country since the end of the war. They took place in close succession beginning around 8.30 am. The first was at the St Sebastian Church in Negombo, a Catholic-majority area. Photographs showed tiles blown off a blackened roof and bloodied bodies on the ground. Two other explosions occurred at St Anthony’s Church in Colombo (another Catholic church), and at the Zion Church (Evangelical) in Batticaloa, around 220km east of the capital.

Around 30 minutes later, there were explosions at the Shangri-La, the Kingsbury and the Cinnamon Grand hotels in Colombo. All are five-star venues and many of the victims were enjoying Easter breakfast special offers. At least 11 foreigners were confirmed killed. Among the nationalities were Indian, Turkish, Portuguese, British and joint US-UK nationals. The authorities counted the bodies of 25 more people presumed to be foreign. The US State Department said “several” Americans had been killed.

Two more explosions took place later in the day, in which eight people were killed, but they appear to be related to security forces’ raids on terrorists’ suspected hideouts. Seven people were arrested.

The main hospital in Colombo was a scene of chaos, with hysterical relatives swarming the narrow road leading to the emergency unit amid a steady flow of ambulances. As news of the attacks spread via social media, police rushed to churches around the country and sent worshippers home. Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith, the head of the Catholic church, cancelled all other services. Security forces were later deployed to guard churches, hotels and the international airport. The government cancelled school for children whose new terms were starting Monday. Universities were declared indefinitely closed. A countrywide police curfew came into effect in the afternoon.

Whoever the perpetrators may be, there are worries that the blasts will stir renewed inter-communal strife. Of Sri Lanka’s population of more than 20m people, about 75% are Sinhalese (who are mostly Buddhists). Tamils, living mostly in the north and east, make up about 11% and are predominantly Hindu. The rebellion by the Tamil Tigers lasted for 27 years. Muslims make up about 9% and speak Tamil. Although they did not join the Tamil Tigers’s rebellion—and indeed some were evicted from the north by them—after the war Muslims have become the target of Budhist nationalist attacks. Christians, mostly Roman Catholics, make up about 7% of the population and straddle the Sinhalese-Tamil divide.

“The puzzle was why the Catholic church was targeted,” said Jayadeva Uyangoda, a political scientist. The spread of Catholicism dates to 1505 with Portuguese colonisation and subsequent proselytization. Catholics permeate all levels of governance, the private sector and even the army, but they were not a particular focus of Tamil Tiger attacks during the civil war.

St Anthony’s church is patronised by both Tamils and Sinhalese, including non-Christians. Any assaults in recent times against Christians—also by Buddhist extremist groups—have been aimed against new Evangelical churches.

Hence the speculation about “foreign actors”, as Cardinal Ranjith put it—in particular Muslim extremists. Only a few dozen Sri Lankan Muslims are thought to have joined the tens of thousands of foreigners who volunteered to fight with the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria. Some have worried about more radical forms of Islam being introduced to the island by contact with foreign preachers. Most alarming, in January Sri Lankan police said they uncovered a large cache of explosives at an IS training camp in the north of the country; it was apparently intended for use against several Buddhist monuments in the ancient city of Anuradhapura.

One reason to worry about the possible radicalisation of Muslims is that Sinhalese Buddhist extremists have sought to instigate and coordinate mob violence against them. A traffic incident in 2018 in which a Sinhalese truck driver was assaulted by four Muslim men (and subsequently died) resulted in days of attacks on Muslim homes and businesses and a large number of injuries. Earlier, in 2014, there was Buddhist-Muslim sectarian violence in several towns in the south fired by the racist speech by a Buddhist monk, Galagodatte Gnarasara, who is now in prison for contempt of court (on a separate matter).

After the Easter bombings, as rumours and incendiary anti-Muslim comments spread like wildfire, the government swiftly shut down all social-media platforms, including WhatsApp, Viber, Facebook and YouTube.

As the hunt for the perpetrators begins, Sri Lanka will be counting the cost of a day of carnage it had not expected. The Catholic church is preparing for mass funerals, which the government has said it will pay for. The country as a whole has suffered a blow to its lucrative tourism sector. Until Easter day it had enjoyed a reputation as one of the safest countries for holidaymakers. That has changed utterly, along with much else.

法官报告中对典狱长猛烈抨击

聚会非常热闹。
We had a blast at the party.
我们在聚会上玩得很开心。
She had the car stereo on at full blast.
她把汽车音响开到了最大音量。
She had the car stereo on at full blast.
她把汽车音响开到了最大音量。

他们在飞机跑道上炸了一个大坑。

危险！爆破进行中！

这部影片受到了所有评论家的严厉抨击。

他飞脚将球踢过了守门员。
He blasted(= shot) the policeman right between the eyes.
他对着那个警察的眉心开了一枪。

一场晚霜把他们的庄稼全毁了。
Oh blast! The car won't start.
